summary.text_en: Hipparchus was greatest astronomer of antiquity! He compiled first star catalog, recording positions of over 1000 stars. He discovered precession of equinoxes, measured distances to Moon and Sun, invented magnitude system. His work laid foundation for later Ptolemaic astronomy.

story.text_en: In 134 BC, Hipparchus observed a new star (supernova) on Rhodes. This made him realize sky not eternally unchanging. He decided to compile complete star catalog, recording all visible star positions for future comparison. Using crude instruments, spending decades, he measured positions of over 1000 stars. Comparing his observations with records from 150 years earlier, he discovered vernal equinox slowly moving - this is precession!

fun_facts.text_en: His magnitude system (1st magnitude brightest, 6th faintest) still used today, just extended to negative numbers and decimals.
His calculated Moon distance of 30.2 Earth diameters amazingly close to modern value of 30.1!
He invented trigonometry, creating first sine table (then called chord table).
Most of his works lost, we know his work mainly through Ptolemy's citations.

experiment.description_en: Hipparchus compared his observed vernal equinox position with astronomers' records from 150 years earlier. He found vernal equinox moved west about 2 degrees relative to star background! This meant Earth's rotation axis slowly wobbling, like spinning top's axis wobbles. He calculated complete cycle about 36000 years (modern value 25772 years). This discovery proved sky not eternally unchanging, opening path for later astronomy development.
experiment.why_en: Earth's rotation axis affected by Moon and Sun's gravity, producing slow conical wobble, causing vernal equinox position change.

simple_explanation.text_en: Imagine playing with spinning top. When top spins, its axis slowly wobbles in circle, right? Earth same way! Earth like big top spinning, its axis also slowly wobbling. Hipparchus discovered this wobble by comparing star positions from different periods. He also ranked stars: brightest are 1st magnitude, faintest 6th magnitude. Like ranking students!

impact.text_en: Hipparchus transformed astronomy from philosophical speculation to precise observational science. His star catalog was humanity's first systematic sky recording, providing valuable reference for later astronomers. His precession discovery proved universe changing, challenging 'eternal unchanging sky' notion. His invented trigonometry became important tool for astronomy and mathematics. Ptolemy's astronomical system largely built on Hipparchus's work foundation.

influenced.contribution_en: Magnitude system and trigonometry still in use

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Hipparchus inherited measurement methods from predecessors like Aristarchus and Eratosthenes, utilizing Babylonians' long-term observation records. His star catalog and precession discovery included in Ptolemy's 'Almagest', influencing 1500 years. Copernicus used his data establishing heliocentrism. Tycho inherited his precise observation tradition. His invented magnitude system and trigonometry still basic tools of astronomy today.

quiz.question_en: What is the precession phenomenon Hipparchus discovered?
quiz.explanation_en: Precession is slow wobble of Earth's rotation axis, causing vernal equinox to move west about 50 arcseconds yearly relative to star background. Hipparchus discovered this by comparing observation records from different periods. Complete precession cycle about 26000 years, meaning North Star position also slowly changing. This discovery proved sky not eternally unchanging.
